name: Taurine
summary: Taurine is a naturally occurring amino sulfonic acid with roles in neurological function, cardiovascular health, electrolyte regulation, and antioxidant defense.
description: Taurine is not incorporated into proteins but is abundant in excitable tissues such as the brain, retina, heart, and skeletal muscle. It supports osmoregulation, calcium signaling, bile salt formation, and neurotransmission. As a supplement, taurine is explored for cardiovascular support, anxiety modulation, neuroprotection, and exercise performance. It is generally well tolerated and also widely consumed in energy drinks, though doses in supplements are usually more controlled.

metadata.natural_source: Endogenously synthesized; abundant in meat and seafood
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

primary_indications: Cardiovascular health (e.g., blood pressure, heart function)
contraindications: Use with caution in individuals with hypotension or on antihypertensive medication
monitoring_required: Blood pressure (if hypertensive or on antihypertensives)

items: Adjunctive support for cardiovascular function and blood pressure regulation
Explored for anxiolytic and neuroprotective properties
Used in exercise performance, reducing fatigue and supporting recovery
May support retinal and metabolic health

sections.text: Taurine modulates GABAergic and glycinergic neurotransmission, stabilizes cell membranes, regulates calcium homeostasis, and acts as an antioxidant. It conjugates bile acids, supporting fat digestion. Its role in osmoregulation and mitochondrial stabilization also contributes to cytoprotection.

adult.typical: 500 mg to 3,000 mg daily in divided doses
adult.note: Often used at 1–2 g/day for general health; doses up to 6 g/day studied for cardiovascular/metabolic conditions.

sections.pediatric: Limited evidence; use only under clinical supervision.

sections.text: Acute effects (e.g., reduced fatigue) may occur within hours; cardiovascular and neuroprotective benefits may require weeks to months.

serious: Rare; high doses generally well tolerated

other: High intake from energy drinks may be unsafe due to caffeine and other additives, not taurine itself.
Caution in patients on antihypertensives or diuretics due to additive effects.

items.risk: Possible changes in lithium levels due to electrolyte effects

items: Exercise tolerance if used for performance

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless supervised
sections.lactation: Unknown safety; avoid unless clinically indicated

sections.text: No tapering required; taurine can be discontinued without withdrawal.

items: Taurine is abundant in diet (meat, seafood); deficiency is rare except in strict vegans or certain medical conditions.
Most supplemental use focuses on cardiovascular, neurological, and exercise support.
Energy drink formulations often pair taurine with high caffeine, which may confound perceived effects.
